questions.question: Define the term activation energy.
questions.answer: The minimum amount of energy particles need to collide with for a reaction to occur.

questions.question: Explain why increasing temperature increases the rate of reaction.
questions.answer: Particles have more kinetic energy, so a greater proportion have energy ≥ activation energy, leading to more frequent successful collisions.

questions.question: State Le Chatelier’s principle.
questions.answer: If a change is applied to a system in equilibrium, the position of equilibrium shifts to oppose that change.

questions.question: Explain the effect of increasing pressure on the position of equilibrium for reactions involving gases.
questions.answer: Equilibrium shifts to the side with fewer moles of gas to oppose the increase in pressure.

questions.question: Define the term enthalpy change.
questions.answer: The heat energy change under constant pressure.

questions.question: Explain why exothermic reactions have negative enthalpy changes.
questions.answer: Energy is released to the surroundings, so the products have less energy than the reactants.

questions.question: State the meaning of the term standard enthalpy of combustion.
questions.answer: The enthalpy change when 1 mole of a substance is completely burned in oxygen under standard conditions.

questions.question: Explain why bond breaking is endothermic.
questions.answer: Energy must be supplied to overcome attractive forces between atoms in a bond.

questions.question: Define the term catalyst.
questions.answer: A substance that increases the rate of reaction by providing an alternative pathway with lower activation energy, and is chemically unchanged at the end.

questions.question: Explain how a catalyst increases the rate of a reaction.
questions.answer: It provides an alternative reaction pathway with lower activation energy, so a greater proportion of particles have energy ≥ Ea.

questions.question: State the definition of dynamic equilibrium.
questions.answer: The forward and reverse reactions occur at the same rate and the concentrations of reactants and products remain constant.

questions.question: Describe what happens to the equilibrium constant Kc when temperature changes.
questions.answer: For an exothermic reaction, Kc decreases when temperature increases; for an endothermic reaction, Kc increases.

questions.question: Define the term rate of reaction.
questions.answer: The change in concentration of a reactant or product per unit time.

questions.question: Explain why increasing the concentration of a reactant increases the rate of reaction.
questions.answer: More particles per unit volume → more frequent collisions → more successful collisions.

questions.question: Define the term reversible reaction.
questions.answer: A reaction in which the products can react to reform the reactants.
